page.title: 01In and around Dunblane
page.content: The 13th century Cathedral and old town lie on the east bank of the Allan Water in a narrow glen where the main south-north road and railway cross the river. New houses lie on hills to east and west, the western section separated from the town centre by the busy A9. A promised by-pass is eagerly awaited. The panorama of mountains to west and north is dramatic. The country is rolling, wooded and intensively farmed. Using excellent rail and road communications many inhabitants are commuters, working all over central Scotland; this is a mobile population with young families, many English. Tradesmen, shopkeepers, professional and retired people are the stable element. The historic town, close to the Perthshire Highlands attracts the tourists.
